Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Social Computation: Fundamental Limits and Efficient Algorithms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Social computing systems bring enormous value to society by harnessing the data generated by members of a community. While each individual alone can offer only limited knowledge, time, and effort, a crowd together can solve challenging societal problems. General approaches to aggregate such data from crowds exists, but are typically suboptimal and inefficient. This project applies information-theoretic techniques to explore the fundamental sample/computation/accuracy trade-offs in social computing. The success of the proposed research will make progress towards a society that efficiently learns from the activities of its members for greater societal good. The proposed research is strongly integrated with an education plan that aims to develop a new graduate course on algorithmic foundations of social computing and innovative adaptive learning platforms that integrates the technology of social computing into the domain of education.

The project will investigate several topics: (1) characterizing the fundamental trade-offs between the available budget and the accuracy of the answers in crowd-sourcing platforms, by applying information-theoretic tools and methods; (2) designing efficient algorithms achieving this fundamental trade-off using techniques from spectral graph theory and coding theory, as well as by applying a family of novel rank-breaking approaches to reduce complexity; and (3) characterizing the three-way fundamental trade-offs between computational complexity, sample size, and accuracy in aggregating preferences from partially observed traces of online and mobile activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provides fundamental limits and efficient algorithms to learn from crowdsourced data and provide personalized recommendations. The mathematical tools include matrix factorization, spectral analysis, convex optimization, and probabilistic graphical models. More broadly, we provide techniques to allow for social computation, where data is shared among numerous users in the system to harness the patterns that will help the individuals benefit from such wisdom from the crowd. We address several challenges including errors in the collected data and the heterogeneity of the users (and their data). Concretely, we provide solutions for aggregating the answers from the crowd reliably. We provide algorithms for providing personalized recommendations from partial preferences of the participating users. We provide meta-learning algorithms that can effectively utilize the heterogeneity inherent in all real-world shared datasets to achieve optimal performances. We augment these algorithms with robustness and privacy: important properties for safe deployment of such algorithms in the wild, especially when the data is collected from numerous sources not all of which are trusted. 

The outcomes of this project will have a broad impact on providing algorithms that serve the purpose of social good. In particular, we provide new algorithms for data sharing platforms that can achieve both robustness and privacy. Robustness refers to the property of the algorithm to withstand a fraction of the data being corrupted by malicious participants in the data sharing. Privacy refers to provable guarantees to provide differential privacy, a mathematical notion of widely accepted privacy, on the data sharing algorithms. This we believe will have an impact beyond statistical machine learning, and help make the society go beyond siloed data centers and freely share data without necessarily trusting all the participants.
